awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Agriculture, Pastoralism And Environmental Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Ryan Szymanski, Ph.D. candidate at Washington State University, collaborating with archaeologists and paleoecologists in the United States and Kenya, will investigate the social and environmental conditions under which food production emerged as a viable, specialized lifeway in East Africa by integrating multi-proxy paleoecological and archaeological data sets. One important aspect of the origins of food production is increased human impact on local ecologies.  The dynamic nature of relationships between humans and their physical and cultural environments throughout prehistory has come under increasing scientific scrutiny in recent years, and both archaeological and paleoecological studies are ideally suited to provide nuanced information detailing these processes.  A major challenge in the reconstruction and interpretation of these contexts is having confidence in attributing the causes of  environmental change to climatic and/or human activity.  More detailed understanding of the ways in which human landscape alteration and climatic change have impacted environments on both local and regional scales over time will improve the ability of authorities, in both private and public spheres, to better construct long-term land management strategies in anticipation of future change.  Primary project data will be  disseminated to local and regional management entities to facilitate future resource stewardship, while a program of  public  presentations is designed to  educate local communities about the importance of resource stewardship..  

Processes of domestication are now understood to include not only individual plant and animal species, but entire ecological and geographic landscapes.  Viewed from this perspective, human activities leading ultimately to highly specialized, "domesticated" plant and animal species are identifiable in environmental and temporal contexts far earlier than when they become visible as significant changes in physical form.  Specifically, this project seeks to answer questions of when, and in what contexts, specialized food production emerges, as well as what strategies have been used to selectively modify floral and faunal presence on given landscapes.  The Central Rift
Valley, Western Highlands, and Coastal regions of modern Kenya, contexts where these processes are not well documented, but which are reasonably well known archaeologically, will be the regional foci for this research. The researchers will examine changes through time in the pollen, fungal spore, and phytolith (diagnostic microscopic mineral accretions found among the cells of many plant groups) record preserved in wetland and lake catchments near known archaeological sites, and  contextualize both types of data in order to better understand environmental changes associated with specific human activities.

por.por_cntn:
This project has approached questions relating to the origins of food production in East Africa that past scholars have had little success addressing with traditional archaeological excavation and survey methods. Little is known of the history of plant cultivation and agriculture in this part of the world. This is largely owing to the fact that, despite concerted efforts, very little in the way of ancient plant food remains (e.g. cereal grains, rachis fragments, etc,…) has been recovered by archaeologists working in this region. This study instead focused on microscopic plant remains such as pollen, phytoliths (silica deposits that develop within and between plant cells in certain plant families), and microscopic charcoal remains, as well as fungal spores associated with certain plant varieties, animal dung, and soil erosion, all of which are more widely distributed than actual physical remains of food production and processing activities, such as charred grains and animal bones. These materials are deposited by wind, animal movements, overland water movement, and by other means, into permanently wet environments such as lakes and swamps, and tend to preserve well in these environments. These materials are useful in the tasks of reconstructing environmental conditions and identifying human activity through time.

            Our results show that the spores of certain fungal parasites which specifically target grain crops such as maize, millets, and sorghums are found only found in any number in association with the pollen of these crop plants. Pollen types that thrive in open and disturbed areas, such as tilled fields and frequently trampled and/or burned areas are more abundant in scenarios where cultivation and animal husbandry is in evidence. Additionally, fungal spore types that indicate soil erosion appear in greater numbers alongside evidence for these disturbance activities. Phytolith evidence also supports these findings, as phytolith types associated with certain cultivated plant types and dry and/or wet conditions vary alongside these lines of evidence as well. Microscopic charcoal fragments appear in greater frequency and size in contexts where human activity is in evidence.

            These results are of broader intellectual importance for several reasons. First, this project has demonstrated, as it has been in some other world regions, that early cultivation activity can be rendered visible by using multiple lines of microscopic evidence, even when more direct evidence such as grains and food processing equipment is poorly documented archaeologically.  This invites a reexamination of previously known archaeological sites and materials from which similar information might be gained, and furthermore, indicates that reinvigoration of attempts to recover such evidence as part of archaeological research in East Africa is warranted. Following this, these findings and similar future research will allow researchers to hypothesize with greater confidence regarding the historical chronology of regions of East Africa where the role of plant cultivation in ancient life was suspect or poorly known. Finally, being able to construct a vegetation and microbial “profile” of given areas through time has yielded a much firmer sense of how local environments react when subjected to discrete activities and climate changes. After full dissemination, this will allow local communities and management authorities to more accurately predict the scope of ecological changes to these areas under different management strategies.


Last Modified: 10/10/2016
Modified by: Andrew I Duff
